subject: Home & DIY
title: How Plague Spread Through Bad Plumbing
description: A micro-lesson that makes How Plague Spread Through Bad Plumbing usable.

hook.text: The Black Death killed 30-60% of Europe. While fleas were the main vector, contaminated water amplified every outbreak.

buildup.text: Medieval cities drew drinking water from wells next to cesspits. Groundwater contamination was universal and invisible.

discovery.text: Typhoid, dysentery, and cholera spread through fecal-contaminated water, weakening populations and fueling plague.

twist.text: Cities with better waterâ€”like Islamic cities with separated supply and wasteâ€”saw lower death rates during outbreaks.

climax.text: Europe's failure to keep Roman sanitation may have doubled plague deaths. Collapsed systems killed more than armies.

punchline.text: The deadliest plague needed the dirtiest water to thrive.

quiz.question: How did poor water infrastructure worsen plague outbreaks in medieval Europe?
options: Contaminated water spread diseases that weakened populations before plague hit
Stagnant water bred the mosquitoes that carried plague bacteria
Flooded streets forced rats into closer contact with humans
